artciles.q: What kind of connections exist between units of same pool?
artciles.description: Units of same pool are mutually inhibitory

artciles.q: If one unit of a pool gets higher activation, how does that affect the activation of other units in the same pool?
artciles.description: since connection is inhibitory,activation of others decreases

artciles.q: net input is dependent on which of the following?
artciles.description: It is dependent on preevious input as well in accord with theory.

artciles.q: How is the change in activation calculated?
option: depends on the sign of net input
artciles.answer: depends on the sign of net input
artciles.description: if net input is +ve, then (a) and if -ve, then (b)

artciles.q: If two units have excitatory connection, and one is activated, what is the phenomenon that both display?
artciles.description: excitation of one activates the other through +ve connection

artciles.q: Is it possible for a unit to not get activated even on giving external input?
option: Yes, because the gamma and decay values may be such that inhibitory power exceeds the external input.
Yes, because external input alone is not enough to activate the unit.
artciles.answer: Yes, because the gamma and decay values may be such that inhibitory power exceeds the external input.
artciles.description: In rare cases, 2nd effect appears

artciles.q: What is the change 'decay' tries to make to the model?
option: bring activation down as much as possible.
bring activation up as much as possible.
tends to restore the activation of the unit to its resting level.
artciles.answer: tends to restore the activation of the unit to its resting level.
artciles.description: it's purpose is not to minimize but rather bring to rest

artciles.q: What is the difference between hidden and visible units in IAC?
option: visible can recieve external input but hidden cannot.
visible affects the activation of other units whereas hidden does not.
visible is shown to the user whereas hidden is not even shown to the user.
artciles.answer: visible can recieve external input but hidden cannot.
artciles.description: theory

artciles.q: how many phases are involved to make sure activation of the units is synchronous?
artciles.description: 'getting net' and 'updating'

artciles.q: Which is the special pool in all pool-projection models?
artciles.description: theory

artciles.q: why is there an actmax and actmin bound on activation?
option: to control activation in cases when estr, decay, gamma have outlying values.
to control rapid change in activation
artciles.answer: to control activation in cases when estr, decay, gamma have outlying values.
artciles.description: rapid change in activation is there irrespective.

artciles.q: What is the nature of the connetions?
option: unidirectional from instance pool to other pools
unidirectional from other pools to instance pool
artciles.description: theory

artciles.q: What makes this model interactive
option: ability of controlling the initial variables
artciles.description: the activation of one unit both influences and is influenced by the units to which it is connected

artciles.q: Which of the following is correct way to choose actmax,actrest and actmin
artciles.description: if rest is +ve, network behaves very oddly

artciles.q: When is equilibrium said to be attained
option: when the net input tends to 0
when the global change tends to 0
artciles.answer: when the global change tends to 0
artciles.description: theory

artciles.q: what is the meaning of competition in IAC
option: tendency for units connected by negative weights to turn each other off
tendency for global change to become 0
tendency for each unit to attain maximum activation
artciles.answer: tendency for units connected by negative weights to turn each other off
artciles.description: theory

artciles.q: what is the name for the ability of one active unit to stop a unit to which it is connected with a negative weight from becoming active?
artciles.description: blocking and hysterisis ensures negative weights reduce activation

artciles.q: what is oscillation?
option: for net input to change signs after every 350 cycles.
ability of some networks turn on and off on consecutive timesteps and never settle to a stable point.
ability of instance pool units to have changing activation
artciles.answer: ability of some networks turn on and off on consecutive timesteps and never settle to a stable point.
artciles.description: theory

artciles.q: Assuming actmax = 1 and actrest = 0, which of the following holds true?
artciles.description: on writing out equations, you get above results

artciles.q: What is the effect of differences in net input over long period of time?
option: the differences remain more or less the same
artciles.description: due to competition, differences can only increase.

artciles.q: Suppose we have two units with mutually inhibitory connections of -2 decay. Unit 1 begins with an activation of 0.5 and both units have external input of decay. Supposing rest is 0:
option: The activation of unit 1 = 0.5,  activation of unit 2 = 0
The activation of unit 1 = 1,  activation of unit 2 = 0.5
The activation of unit 1 = 0.5,  activation of unit 2 = 0.5
artciles.answer: The activation of unit 1 = 0.5,  activation of unit 2 = 0
artciles.description: delta Ai formula.

artciles.q: which of these themes are central to neural networks and not present in sequential processing machines?
artciles.description: both aspects cannot be performed by Von Neumann machines that only sequentially process

artciles.q: which of these themes are central to neural networks and not present in sequential processing machines?
artciles.description: both aspects cannot be performed by Von Neumann machines that only sequentially process

artciles.q: Which of the following correctly defines content addressibility
option: the ability to access memories given any of the components of the fact or episode.
the ability to access memories despite incomplete or even incorrect cues.
the ability to generalise over a set of instances.
the ability to assign plausible default values if a given fact is not in memory.
artciles.answer: the ability to access memories given any of the components of the fact or episode.
artciles.description: theory

artciles.q: Which of the following correctly defines robustness to noise
option: the ability to access memories given any of the components of the fact or episode.
the ability to access memories despite incomplete or even incorrect cues.
the ability to generalise over a set of instances.
the ability to assign plausible default values if a given fact is not in memory.
artciles.answer: the ability to access memories despite incomplete or even incorrect cues.
artciles.description: theory
